Eigenvalues: Spectral Decomposition

Michael Friendly

2024-10-05

Source: vignettes/eigen-ex2.Rmd
eigen-ex2.Rmd
library(matlib)   # use the package

Setup

This vignette uses an example of a 3√ó33 \times 3 matrix to illustrate some properties of eigenvalues and eigenvectors. We could consider this to be the variance-covariance matrix of three variables, but the main thing is that the matrix is square and symmetric, which guarantees that the eigenvalues, Œªi\lambda_i are real numbers, and non-negative, Œªi‚â•0\lambda_i \ge 0.

A <- matrix(c(13, -4, 2, -4, 11, -2, 2, -2, 8), 3, 3, byrow=TRUE)
A
##      [,1] [,2] [,3]
## [1,]   13   -4    2
## [2,]   -4   11   -2
## [3,]    2   -2    8

Get the eigenvalues and eigenvectors using eigen(); this returns a named list, with eigenvalues named values and eigenvectors named vectors. We call these L and V here, but in formulas they correspond to a diagonal matrix, ùö≤=diag(Œª1,Œª2,Œª3)\mathbf{\Lambda} = diag(\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \lambda_3), and a (orthogonal) matrix ùêï\mathbf{V}.

ev <- eigen(A)
# extract components
(L <- ev$values)
## [1] 17  8  7
(V <- ev$vectors)
##         [,1]    [,2]   [,3]
## [1,]  0.7454  0.6667 0.0000
## [2,] -0.5963  0.6667 0.4472
## [3,]  0.2981 -0.3333 0.8944

Matrix factorization

  1. Factorization of A: A = V diag(L) V‚Äô. That is, the matrix ùêÄ\mathbf{A} can be represented as the product ùêÄ=ùêïùö≤ùêï‚Ä≤\mathbf{A}= \mathbf{V} \mathbf{\Lambda} \mathbf{V}'.
V %*% diag(L) %*% t(V)
##      [,1] [,2] [,3]
## [1,]   13   -4    2
## [2,]   -4   11   -2
## [3,]    2   -2    8
  1. V diagonalizes A: L = V‚Äô A V. That is, the matrix ùêï\mathbf{V} transforms ùêÄ\mathbf{A} into the diagonal matrix ùö≤\mathbf{\Lambda}, corresponding to orthogonal (uncorrelated) variables.
diag(L)
##      [,1] [,2] [,3]
## [1,]   17    0    0
## [2,]    0    8    0
## [3,]    0    0    7
zapsmall(t(V) %*% A %*% V)
##      [,1] [,2] [,3]
## [1,]   17    0    0
## [2,]    0    8    0
## [3,]    0    0    7

Spectral decomposition

The basic idea here is that each eigenvalue‚Äìeigenvector pair generates a rank 1 matrix, ŒªiùêØiùêØi‚Ä≤\lambda_i \mathbf{v}_i \mathbf{v}_i ', and these sum to the original matrix, ùêÄ=‚àëiŒªiùêØiùêØi‚Ä≤\mathbf{A} = \sum_i \lambda_i \mathbf{v}_i \mathbf{v}_i '.

A1 = L[1] * V[,1] %*% t(V[,1])
A1
##        [,1]   [,2]   [,3]
## [1,]  9.444 -7.556  3.778
## [2,] -7.556  6.044 -3.022
## [3,]  3.778 -3.022  1.511
A2 = L[2] * V[,2] %*% t(V[,2])
A2
##        [,1]   [,2]    [,3]
## [1,]  3.556  3.556 -1.7778
## [2,]  3.556  3.556 -1.7778
## [3,] -1.778 -1.778  0.8889
A3 = L[3] * V[,3] %*% t(V[,3])
A3
##      [,1] [,2] [,3]
## [1,]    0  0.0  0.0
## [2,]    0  1.4  2.8
## [3,]    0  2.8  5.6

Then, summing them gives A, so they do decompose A:

A1 + A2 + A3
##      [,1] [,2] [,3]
## [1,]   13   -4    2
## [2,]   -4   11   -2
## [3,]    2   -2    8
all.equal(A, A1+A2+A3)
## [1] TRUE

Further properties

  1. Sum of squares of A = sum of sum of squares of A1, A2, A3
sum(A^2)
## [1] 402
c( sum(A1^2), sum(A2^2), sum(A3^2) )
## [1] 289  64  49
sum( sum(A1^2), sum(A2^2), sum(A3^2) )
## [1] 402
#' same as tr(A' A)
tr(crossprod(A))
## [1] 402
  1. Each squared eigenvalue gives the sum of squares accounted for by the latent vector
L^2
## [1] 289  64  49
cumsum(L^2)   # cumulative
## [1] 289 353 402
  1. The first ii eigenvalues and vectors give a rank ii approximation to A 
R(A1)
## [1] 1
R(A1 + A2)
## [1] 2
R(A1 + A2 + A3)
## [1] 3
# two dimensions
sum((A1+A2)^2)
## [1] 353
sum((A1+A2)^2) / sum(A^2)   # proportion
## [1] 0.8781
